finding: Respiratory viruses, such as respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), rhinovirus (RV), and human metapneumovirus (hMPV), are commonly associated with asthma exacerbations.
RSV and RV can cause inflammation and airway reactivity through strain differences and the host immune response.

HMPV has a smaller amount of viral replication and a low number of inflammatory cells in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid of infected mice due to a decreased type I interferon response, potentially leading to a more successful infection.
Atypical bacteria, such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae and Chlamydophila pneumoniae, are also associated with asthma exacerbations, but the mechanisms leading to these conditions are not fully understood.
Preexisting allergic inflammation impairs the ability to up-regulate TLR2 and IL-6 in the lungs, leading to decreased clearance of M. Pneumoniae and an increase in airway inflammation.
